In Praise of Moot Court--Not!
REEL JUSTICE: THE COURTROOM GOES TO THE MOVIES BY PAUL BERGMAN AND MICHAEL ASIMOW, Andrews and McMeel, 1996. 338 pp.

reference.author: Bergman Paul
reference.journal-title: Reel Justice: The Courtroom Goes To The MOVIES

reference.unstructured: 2Judge Alex Kozinski is a United States Circuit Judge for the 9th Circuit and a self-proclaimed movie buff. Perhaps one of the Judge's most notable (notorious?) opinions weaves into its prose the titles to more than 100 movies.SeeU.S. v. Syufy Theatres, 903 F. 2d 659 (1990).

3Michael Asimow is a Professor of Law at the University of California Los Angeles Law School (UCLA) where he teaches contracts, tax and administrative law. Paul Bergman is also a Professor of Law at UCLA where he teaches trial advocacy and evidence.

4Gene Siskel is a noted film critic who previously worked for the Chicago Tribune and, since 1990, has been a film critic for CBSThis Morning.In 1975, Siskel joined Roger Ebert, a Pulitzer Prize-winning film critic for the Chicago Sun-Times, as co-host of the nationally syndicated film review programSiskel & Ebert(Buena Vista Television).

5The movies reviewed include (in alphabetical order): The Accused, An Act of Murder, Adam's Rib, The Advocate, Anatomy of a Murder, And Justice For All, Bananas, Beyond a Reasonable Doubt, Billy Budd, Boomerang, Breaker Morant, The Caine Mutiny, Class Action, Compulsion, The Court-Martial of Billy Mitchell, A Cry in the Dark, The Devil and Daniel Webster, A Few Good Men, Fury, Guilty as Sin, I Confess, I Want to Live, Inherit the Wind, In the Name of the Father, It Could Happen to You, Jagged Edge, Judgment at Nuremberg, Knock on Any Door, Kramer v. Kramer, Let Him Have It, The Letter, Libel, The Life of Emile Zola, Losing Isaiah, A Man for All Seasons, Miracle on 34th Street, Mr. Deeds Goes to Town, Murder in the First, The Music Box, My Cousin Vinny, Nuts, The Onion Field, On Trial, The Ox-Bow Incident, The Paradine Case, Paths of Glory, Philadelphia, A Place in the Sun, Presumed Innocent, Prisoners of the Sun, Reversal of Fortune, Sommersby, The Star Chamber, Suspect, 10 Riliington Place, They Won't Believe Me, They Won't Forget, The Thin Blue Line, To Kill a Mockingbird, Trial, Trial by Jury, Twelve Angry Men, The Verdict, Witness for the Prosecution, Whose Life Is It Anyway? The Wrong Man, Young Mr. Lincoln, The Young Philadelphians. REEL JUSTICE, at 327-329, supra note 1. Robert J. Aalberts, Gideon's Trumpet, 12 J. Legal stud. educ. 321 (1994) (movie review).

7The authors also provide an "Appendix of Additional Courtroom Movies" with one sentence summaries of the plot and their ranking, but do not offer any legal analyses of those films. Reel justice,supranote 1, at 316-19.
8Chapter 1, "The Story You Are About to See Is True...,"Id.at 1-54.

12The authors admitted "We hope this book will help you choose which video to rent next Friday night when you feel that gnawing hunger for a good cross-examination along with your microwave popcorn."Id., at xviii.

16TheMcDonnell Douglasanalysis consists of three main parts: 1) the plaintiff must sustain the burden of proof of establishing a prima facie case of discrimination; 2) the burden then shifts to the defendant to show a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for their action; and 3) the plaintiff then has the opportunity to prove the reason offered is merely pretextual.
20Id.at 276-279. (This movie was based upon an actual occurrence in 1984 involving a suburban New York detective and a waitress with whom he had agreed to split the winnings on a lottery ticket.).

22The movie's plot was obviously based in large part on the case of Grimshaw v. Ford Motor Company, 119 Cal. App. 3d 757, 174 Cal. Rptr. 348 (Cal. App. 1981) (the Ford Pinto case) which, like Class Action, included evidence that the company had done an internal cost-benefit analysis and concluded that the cost to fix the defect would exceed the cost of paying victims of the defective product.

23The authors do clarify that, despite its name, the movieClass Actionreally involves a straightforward products liability claim (wrongful death) brought on behalf of an individual whose wife was killed in an explosion resulting from a car collision. Reel Justice,supra note1, at 275.
275 Ex-Marines Suit Contends Movie Depicts Their Story , Dallas Morning News , 1993 ,at 39A.
28Ex-Marine Who Felt ‘A Few Good Men’ Maligned Him is Mysteriously Murdered , Balt. Sun , 1994 , at 1A.
33This is not surprising, in view of the legal specialties of the authors.See supra, note3.

35Alex Kozinski , Forward to Reel Justice,supranote 1 at xiii ("Its only defect, alas, is that it is too short: Where do you get the skinny onFirst Monday in October, The Story of Qui Ju, The Return of Martin Guerre, and Hang "Em High?I, for one, have already put in my order for Reel Justice II.").

36AlsbTalk is an E-mail list-server designed to allow members of the Academy of Legal Studies in Business to communicate instantaneously. Members can subscribe by sending the message "sub ALSBTALK firstname lastname" to listserv@miamiu. muohio.edu.
